channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Biden Arrives in Brussels for Summits as U.S. Accuses Russian Forces of War Crimes
item.description: President Biden will press allies to help impose even more aggressive sanctions on Russia. NATO says it is doubling the number of battlegroups on its eastern flank to eight.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters battled a fire at a residence on the west side of Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, after a Russian multiple rocket attack on Wednesday morning.

item.title: A Town on Ukraine’s Edge, Determined to Escape Its Past
item.description: Przemysl’s history has been intertwined with war. This time, like much of Poland, it wants to do things differently.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk, Jeffrey Gettleman and Erin Schaff
item.media:description: Przemysl, Poland, has opened its doors to Ukrainians fleeing the war. Its train station is a major transit point.

item.title: Taliban Renege on Promise to Open Afghan Girls’ Schools
item.description: The schools were supposed to reopen this week, and the reversal could threaten aid because international officials had made girls’ education a condition for greater assistance.
item.dc:creator: Safiullah Padshah and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Ahmad Sahel Arman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Girls attending a class after their school briefly reopened in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Wednesday, before being quickly shut down again.

item.title: In Asia, Covid-19 Rules Fall Away, With a Big Caveat
item.description: Daily life in the region was once regulated by a snarl of virus restrictions. That is changing fast — except in mainland China, which is still rolling out lockdowns.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez, Mike Ives and Victoria Kim
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Ezra Acayan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Quiapo shopping district in Manila, Philippines, on Friday.

item.title: Ukraine War Ignites Israeli Debate Over Purpose of a Jewish State
item.description: Most Ukrainians seeking refuge in Israel are non-Jews. Some Israelis see a moral imperative to take them in, but others see a threat to the country’s Jewish character.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lida Stryzhkovl, from Kyiv, Ukraine, and her grandson, Dima, waiting at Ben-Gurion Airport's train station, on their way to Beersheba, where a relative lives.

item.title: Russia and Far-Right Americans Find Common Ground With Ukraine War
item.description: Some conservatives have echoed the Kremlin’s misleading claims about the war and vice versa, giving each other’s assertions a sheen of credibility.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:description: The Fox News host Tucker Carlson has echoed Russian claims that the invasion of Ukraine was taken in self-defense. He has also criticized Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin.

item.title: Trying to Solve a Covid Mystery: Africa’s Low Death Rates
item.description: The coronavirus was expected to devastate the continent, but higher-income and better-prepared countries appear to have fared far worse.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A wedding in the village of Kamakuyor in northern Sierra Leone last month. During the pandemic, the village’s district has recorded just 11 Covid cases and no deaths.

item.title: U.N. Investigator Accuses Israel of Apartheid, Citing Permanence of Occupation
item.description: Strongly denied by Israel and its supporters, the claim is the first time that a U.N.-appointed rapporteur has accused Israel of apartheid in such an unequivocal way.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A U.N.-appointed investigator joined other rights watchdogs that have sought to recast the Israeli-Palestinian conflict as a struggle for equal rights instead of a territorial dispute.

item.title: Germany Is Ready to Lead Militarily. Its Military Is Not.
item.description: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine prompted Germany to revolutionize its security doctrine. But the war has also exposed how weak a link the German military is in NATO.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: A German NATO armored personnel carrier during an exercise in Rukla, Lithuania, this month.

item.title: Evan Neumann, Accused in Capitol Riot, Granted Asylum in Belarus
item.description: Evan Neumann, who is wanted by the F.B.I. on charges including assaulting police officers at the Jan. 6 riot in Washington, has been granted asylum in Belarus, officials told state media.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Valeriya Safronova
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters stormed the Capitol in Washington on Jan. 6, 2021. Mr. Neumann has denied striking officers or committing any other crimes during the riot.

item.title: Photographing the Reality of War
item.description: Lynsey Addario, a Times photojournalist in Ukraine, shares her experiences on the ground and how she communicates with her subjects during difficult moments.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Civilians evacuated across the remnants of a destroyed bridge in Irpin, a northwest suburb of Kyiv, Ukraine, this month.

item.title: How Europe Got Hooked on Russian Gas Despite Reagan’s Warnings
item.description: A Soviet-era pipeline, opposed by the president but supported by the oil and gas industry, set up the dependency that today helps fund the Russian assault on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: President Ronald Reagan imposed sanctions in 1981 in an effort to block a Soviet pipleine project, but he soon ran into stiff opposition from industry.

item.title: China Finds Flight Recorder From Plane Crash as Rain Hinders Search
item.description: Officials have revealed few details about the China Eastern Airlines flight that went down Monday, with the government moving quickly to control the information flow and emphasize the positive.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Searching the site of a plane crash on Tuesday, in a photo released by Xinhua, a state news agency.

item.title: U.S. Makes Contingency Plans in Case Russia Uses Its Most Powerful Weapons
item.description: A team of national security officials has been assigned to sketch out responses if President Vladimir V. Putin unleashes chemical, biological or nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt, Helene Cooper and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Biden arrived in Brussels on Wednesday, where he will meet with NATO leaders.

item.title: U.S. Officials Meet With Brittney Griner in Russia
item.description: Some former hostages question whether the family should remain silent, saying pressure campaigns can work.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz, Jonathan Abrams and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, one of the most prominent and decorated athletes in American sports, is languishing in a Russian cell on drug charges.

item.title: As Biden Visits Europe Over Crisis, NATO Says It’s Doubling Eastern Flank Forces
item.description: The alliance also said it would assist Ukraine because of chemical, biological and nuclear threats posed by Russia in the month-old invasion.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, David E. Sanger and Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: President Biden and Prime Minister Alexander De Croo of Belgium in Brussels on Wednesday. Mr. Biden visited Europe for an extraordinary strategy session with the NATO alliance.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: NATO Boosts Its Eastern Presence
item.description: Plus Asia’s disappearing Covid rules and the Taliban’s reversal on girls’ schools.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: German soldiers attached to the Lithuania-based NATO battlegroup undergoing training this month.

item.title: With Eye to Russia, Biden Administration Asks Companies to Report Cyberattacks
item.description: A new law requires companies to tell the federal government about hacks, but the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency still has to work out the details of what must be reported.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger
item.media:description: Fuel storage tanks connected to the Colonial Pipeline system in Baltimore. A cyberattack disrupted the pipeline’s operations last year.

item.title: The U.S. Government Accuses Russian Forces of War Crimes
item.description: In a statement, the U.S. secretary of state, Antony J. Blinken, cited the destruction of “apartment buildings, schools, hospitals, critical infrastructure, civilian vehicles, shopping centers, and ambulances.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firemen and emergency workers on Monday at the ruins of the Retroville Mall, a shopping center in Kyiv, the capital, after a powerful explosion.

item.title: Julian Assange Marries Stella Moris in a British Prison
item.description: The wedding took place at Belmarsh Prison, where Mr. Assange has been held since 2019. Supporters of the couple were encouraged to attend a “solidarity vigil” outside the facility.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Stella Moris cut a wedding cake given to her by supporters at Belmarsh Prison in southeast London, where she married the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange on Wednesday.

item.title: Top Virologist Who Visited a Wuhan Market in 2014 Said He Found
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

item.title: U.S. Capitol to Reopen Tours Next Week
item.description: Tours of the Capitol were suspended for about two years over the pandemic and security concerns related to the Jan. 6 riot.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. Capitol in Washington on Monday.

item.title: Israel Blocked Sale of Pegasus Spyware to Ukraine and Estonia
item.description: The Eastern European countries had sought to buy Pegasus, spyware made by an Israeli firm, to carry out intelligence operations against Russia, according to people with knowledge of the discussions.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Mark Mazzetti
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine criticized Israel for not providing his country with the Iron Dome antimissile system and other defensive weapons during a speech on Sunday.

item.title: NATO Doubles Troop Presence in Eastern Europe Ahead of Summit
item.description: The alliance’s secretary general announced the deployment of new battlegroups in Bulgaria, Hungary, Romania and Slovakia. NATO has four others in the region.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: German soldiers attached to the Lithuania-based NATO battlegroup undergoing training this month.

item.title: Could a Crackdown on Oligarchs Help Ukraine?
item.description: Russian oligarchs helped boost Vladimir V. Putin’s influence in the West. Can sanctions turn that pressure back on him?
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: A group of squatters on the balcony of a mansion in London’s Belgrave Square earlier this month.

item.title: Putin’s Climate Envoy Steps Down, Reportedly Over the Ukraine War
item.description: The envoy, Anatoly Chubais, was reported to have become the senior-most Russian government official to quit over the invasion.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski

item.title: Dutch Publisher of ‘The Betrayal of Anne Frank’ Halts Publication
item.description: The move came after five historians called into question the findings of the book, in which a “cold case” team sought to answer a long-running mystery.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.media:credit: Sem Van Der Wal/ANP, via Agence France-Presse

item.title: Wrecked Whaling Ship Offers Glimpse of U.S. Racial History
item.description: A shipwreck in the Gulf of Mexico has been identified and the mystery of its multiracial crew’s fate unraveled.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:description: An anchor at the bottom of the Gulf of Mexico where the whaling ship Industry capsized and sank in 1836.

item.title: Zelensky Addresses Japan’s Parliament, Invoking Memories of Fukushima
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said that Russia’s invasion could set off a nuclear catastrophe in Chernobyl and warned that Russia could use chemical weapons like the one used in a 1995 attack in Tokyo.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley
item.media:description: Members of Japan's lower house Parliament applauded on Wednesday in Tokyo as President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine delivered a virtual address to them.

item.title: Nine Mass Shootings
item.description: A violent weekend highlights America’s continuing crime wave.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Rory Doyle for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shell casing in the parking lot at the scene of a shooting in Dumas, Ark.

item.title: Ukrainian Cellist Plays Bach in the Ruins of His Hometown, Kharkiv
item.description: Denys Karachevtsev said on social media that he hoped his performance would bring aid and attention for Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second largest city, which has been heavily bombarded.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins

item.title: China’s Divorce Rate Is Down, but So Are Marriages
item.description: While officials say a new law has helped save marriages, the bigger challenge in the country’s demographic crisis is that fewer people are getting married in the first place.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: A Chinese couple celebrating their wedding, outside the Forbidden City in Beijing.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s advance falters.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: Hillsong’s Brian Houston Resigns Amid Scandals
item.description: Brian Houston was accused of breaching the church’s code of conduct after two women said he had behaved inappropriately.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mick Tsikas/Australian Associated Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Brian Houston in Sydney, Australia, in 2014. He resigned after an internal investigation into allegations he had behaved inappropriately toward two women.

item.title: Here are the latest developments.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah

item.title: Brain Implant Allows Fully Paralyzed Patient to Communicate
item.description: Letter by painstaking letter, a man in a completely locked-in state was able to formulate words and sentences using only his thoughts.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Moens

item.title: South Africa begins to lift Covid restrictions but leaves its indoor mask mandate.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: The weekly Parkrun event in Delta Park in central Johannesburg was resumed this month as South Africa eases Covid restrictions.

item.title: Ukrainians Try to Push Back Russian Forces Pummeling Their Cities
item.description: Desperate fighting has shifted the front lines but neither side seems to have a decisive upper hand as Ukraine’s suffering deepens.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: A civilian guarding a defense checkpoint on the road to Zhytomyr, near the Ukrainian village of Mala Racha on Tuesday. Most of the civilians volunteering with the unit lacked military training.

item.title: Yvan Colonna, Corsican Jailed for French Prefect’s Murder, Dies at 61
item.description: A folk hero for Corsica’s nationalist movement, he evaded a long manhunt but was finally arrested in 2003. He died shortly after being brutally attacked in prison.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: A rally was held for the pro-independence activist Yvan Colonna in the Corsican city of Bastia this month after he was assaulted in prison, where he was serving a life sentence for murder.

item.title: Kremlin Spokesman Says Russia Could Use Nuclear Weapons if There Is ‘An Existential Threat’
item.description: The spokesman, Dmitri S. Peskov, made the comment after describing Ukraine, the neighboring country Russia invaded a month ago, as having been created by anti-Russian Western powers.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:description: A monument of the Soviet tactical nuclear bomb, RDS-4, in Moscow last year.

item.title: Biden Plans Sanctions on Russian Lawmakers as He Heads to Europe
item.description: A chief goal of the meetings this week is to show that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine will not lead to sniping and disagreement among the United States and its allies.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden faces a steep challenge as he works to confront President Vladimir V. Putin’s aggression.

item.title: As Russia Stalls in Ukraine, Dissent Brews Over Putin’s Leadership
item.description: Military losses have mounted, progress has slowed, and a blame game has begun among some Russian supporters of the war.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: Defense Minister Sergei K. Shoigu, second from left, and his top military commander, Gen. Valery Gerasimov, meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin last month.

item.title: Ukraine War and Pandemic Force Nations to Retreat From Globalization
item.description: Conflicts among the U.S., Russia and China — and endless Covid-19 outbreaks — strain the interdependent economy and Western ideas of post-Cold War stability.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Ana Swanson
item.media:description: A woman walks past a closed Louis Vuitton store in Moscow last week. Many American and European countries stopped doing business in Russia after the invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia Extends Navalny’s Sentence
item.description: Plus Pfizer’s plan to send Covid pills to poor countries and efforts to unseat Pakistan’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Police officers detain an elderly woman as she protests against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, in central Moscow on March 20, 2022.

item.title: Coronavirus cases are rising in European nations because restrictions were eased too soon, a W.H.O. official says.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Battersea Park in London on Tuesday. Cases of coronavirus are increasing in 18 European countries, including Britain.

item.title: Russia’s Forces Against Ukraine Have Shrunk, Pentagon Says
item.description: The official said that Russian forces were “struggling on many fronts,” and that there were indications that some troops had been evacuated with frostbite.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:description: Ukrainian forces and civilians inspecting a disabled Russian tank this month. Russia has lost more than 10 percent of its original combat force in fighting Ukrainian troops.

item.title: Four Killed in Southern Israel in Latest in Spate of Attacks
item.description: The attacks have heightened fears of further violence in April, when the convergence of three religious holidays has leaders on edge.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A volunteer emergency response team cleans up the site of an attack in the southern Israeli city of Beersheba on Tuesday.

item.title: Leaders of Israel, U.A.E. and Egypt Meet Amid Shifting Geopolitics
item.description: All three countries are navigating fraught relationships with the Biden administration amid the quickly changing geopolitical landscape precipitated by Russia’s war on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Patrick Kingsley

item.title: Vacations Abruptly End as Tourists Return to a Different Russia
item.description: While Russian tourists were visiting Margarita Island, their country invaded Ukraine. Many were left wondering what travails awaited them back at home.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Isayen Herrera and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The beach at Sunsol Ecoland hotel, a popular destination among Russian tourists, in Margarita, Venezuela.

item.title: ‘OK Doomer’ and the Climate Advocates Who Say It’s Not Too Late
item.description: A growing chorus of young people is focusing on climate solutions. “‘It’s too late’ means ‘I don’t have to do anything, and the responsibility is off me.’”
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Shirley Yu for The New York Times

item.title: Two Teachers Killed at a School in Malmo, Sweden
item.description: The police said they were still trying to determine a motive for the attack in the southern city of Malmo.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson
item.media:credit: Johan Nilsson/TT News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Laying flowers outside Malmo Latin School in Malmo, Sweden, a day after two teachers were killed.

item.title: Canada’s Trudeau Strikes Accord With Opponents to Secure Hold on Power
item.description: A left-of-center opposition party agrees to back the government until 2025 in exchange for advancing its causes.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Jagmeet Singh of the New Democratic Party during an election debate last September.

item.title: Imran Khan, Pakistan’s Prime Minister, Fights for Survival
item.description: Soaring inflation and a rift with the military threaten Imran Khan’s tenure as prime minister. He has dismissed criticism as a foreign conspiracy.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Pakistan’s prime minister, Imran Khan, addressing the nation last month. A troubled economy and a rift with the military threaten his hold on power.

item.title: China Takes a Back Seat in International Diplomacy Over Ukraine
item.description: Despite its economic and military might and close ties to Russia, China has balked at trying to press Vladimir Putin to stop the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Chris Buckley
item.media:description: China’s leader Xi Jinping and President Vladimir Putin of Russia attending a meeting during the BRICS summit in Brasilia, Brazil, in 2019.

item.title: Aleksei Navalny Found Guilty of Fraud by Russian Court
item.description: Despite already being behind bars, Mr. Navalny has been urging Russians to protest the war in Ukraine, making him even more of a liability for President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Valeriya Safronova
item.media:description: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei Navalny, standing at a desk, left, with his lawyers at a makeshift courtroom outside Moscow, as seen on a screen showing a video link from the hearing on Tuesday.

item.title: Here are the latest developments.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky

item.title: Why Ketanji Brown Jackson Is Different
item.description: Ketanji Brown Jackson is similar to and different from the justices she would be joining — not only because of her race and gender.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson during on Capitol Hill yesterday.

item.title: What We Know About the Crash of China Eastern Airlines Flight 5735
item.description: The crash of the Boeing plane, with more than 130 people on board, is China’s worst air disaster in more than a decade.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy and Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: China Eastern Airlines Boeing 737-800 planes at an airport in Taiyuan, Shanxi province, in 2014.
